questions.text: Signs positive in early pregnancy are:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Palmer's sign Regular and rhythmic uterine contraction which can be felt on bimanual examination
  • Hegar's sign On Bimanual examination with 2 fingers in anterior fornix and fingers of other hand behind the uterus, the abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to be below the body of the uterus. occurs because of softening of isthmusQ
  • Goodell's sign Softening of cervix (cervix feels like lip of mouth whereas in non pregnant state it feels like tip of nose)
  • Osiander's sign Increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices
  • Chadwick's sign Dusky hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall due to local vascular conge

questions.text: Hegar's sign of pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hegar's sign is present in 2/3rd cases and is demonstrated between 6 - 10 weeks.
  • The sign is based on the fact that - the upper part of the body is enlarged by the growing fetus whereas the lower part of the body of the uterus, i.e. isthmus is empty and soft and the cervix is comparatively firm. Because of these variations in consistency on bimanual examination, the abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to appear below the body of the uterus.

Explanation of other options:

  • Uterine contraction(Option A): Palmer's sign ;Regular and rhythmic uterine contraction which can be felt on bimanual examination
  • Bluish discoloration of vagina(Option B):Chadwick's sign Dusky hue of the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall due to local vascular conge
  • Quickening(Option D): Refers to maternal perception of fetal movements, usually at 18-20 weeks in primigravida and 16-18 weeks in multigravida,

questions.text: Monitoring of β-hCG is useful in management of all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Endodermal sinus tumors are yolk sac tumors and their markers are Alpha fetoprotein and antitrypsin levels and not beta-hCG. So hCG levels are not used for monitoring
  • β-hCG levels are helpful in monitoring:
  • Hydatidiform mole A method of detecting the persistent mole and development of choriocarcinoma is by estimating hCG is the serum urine(Option A ruled out)
  • Choriocarcinoma: β-hCG is a specific marker for choriocarcinoma. The levels of β-hCG are monitored following chemotherapy and complete regression of tumor is indicated when three consecutive weekly radioimmunoassays of hCG in serum are negative.(Option B ruled out)
  • In case of unruptured ectopic pregnancy which is managed medically with methotrexate or by conservative surgery-monitoring is done by estimating β-hCG levels.Following conservative surgery or medical treatment, estimation of β-hCG should be done weekly till the value becomes< 5.0 mIU/ml.(Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Pregnancy is confirmed by all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Positive or absolute signs of pregnancy:

  • Palpation of fetal parts and perception of fetal movements by examiner, at about 20 weeks.(Option D ruled out)
  • Auscultation of fetal heart sounds.(Option C ruled out)
  • USG evidence of embryo (at 6th week) and later on of the fetus.
  • Radiological demonstration of fetal skeleton at 16 weeks and onwards.
  • Friends there is no need to mug up the presumptive/probable signs of pregnancy. Generally it is not asked in exams.
  • These positive or absolute signs of pregnancy are never seen in pseudocyesis or phantom pregnancy.

questions.text: Best parameter for estimation of fetal age by ultrasound in 3rd trimester is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The best parameter for estimation of fetal age by ultrasound in the 3rd trimester is Femur length.

USG in Pregnancy:

  • Mean sac diameter (CMSD) is used to determine gestational age before CRL can be measured
  • MSD = Length + height + width/3
  • Normal MSD (in mm) + 30 = Days of pregnancy
  • CRL (in mm) + 42 = gestation in days.
  • The embryo should increase its CRL by 1 mm per day.
  • Fetal anomaly which can be earliest detected by USG is Anencephaly.
  • Lemon and Banana sign are seen in spina bifida on USG,
  • The two best ultrasonographic markers of Down syndrome in first trimester:
    • Absent or hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Increased nuchal translucency
  • If a single ultrasound examination is planned for the purpose of evaluating fetal anatomy, ACOG (2011) recommends it to be performed at 18-20 weeks.

Explanation for other options:

Abdominal circumference (Option C): Best indicator of fetal growth is abdominal circumference and hence is the best detector of IUGR and Macrosomia. AC is measured at the junction of Left and Right portal vein or liver and cystic duct

questions.text: Earliest detection of pregnancy by ultrasound is by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A gestational sac is the 1st sonographic evidence of pregnancy, and it may be seen with transvaginal sonography by 4 to 5 weeks gestation.
  • A normal gestational sac implants eccentrically in the endometrium, while a pseudosac lies midline. Early intrauterine pregnancy is suggested by the intradecidual sign (anechoic center with single echogenic rim) or the double decidual sign (two concentric echogenic rings).(Option B,C and D ruled out)

USG in early pregnancy

questions.text: In transvaginal ultrasound, earliest detection of gestation sac is by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The first definitive sonographic finding to suggest early pregnancy is visualization of the gestational sac. Using transvaginal transducers with frequency of 5 MHz, the size threshold for sac detection is 2 - 3 mm,corresponding to 4 weeks + 1 day gestational age to 4 weeks + 3 days gestational age.
  • To understand how many days after ovulation, you should first understand that gestational age is calculated from the 1st day of the

As is evident from the above diagram gestational sac is visualized approximately 15-17 days after ovulation (or within 1-3 days of missed period) but since it is not given in options so the nearest possible answer is 14 days after ovulation.(Option A,B and C ruled out)

questions.text: An expectant mother feels quickening at:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Quickening (feeling of life) denotes the perception of active fetal movements by the women.
  • It is usually felt about the 18th week, 2 weeks earlier in multiparous. Its appearance is a useful guide to calculate the expected date of delivery with reasonable accuracy"(Option A,C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Use of folic acid to prevent congenital malformation should be best initiated:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Folic acid has been shown to effectively reduce the risk of neural tube defects (NTD's).
  • A daily 4 mg dose is recommended for patients who have had a previous pregnancy affected by neural tube defects. It should be started at least 1 month (ideally 3 months) prior to pregnancy and continued through the first 6-12 weeks of pregnancy.
  • More than half of NTDs could be prevented with daily intake of 400 µg of folic acid throughout the periconceptional period.
  • Thus dose of folic acid which is given to all pregnant females =4 mg, i.e. 400 mcg (also called as prophylactic dose).
  • A woman with a prior pregnancy complicated by a neural tube defect can reduce the 23% recurrence risk by more than 70% if she takes 4 mg of folic acid for the month before conception and for the first trimester of pregnancy. This is called a therapeutic dose of folic acid.
  • Therapeutic dose of folic acid (to be given in females with a previous history of baby with NTD)-4 mg.
  • Duration: It should be started 1 month before conception and continued till the first 6-12 weeks of pregnancy.
  • Dose of folic acid given to pregnant women with megaloblastic anemia = 1 mg day.

questions.text: Ideal number of antenatal visits:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • According to World Health Organization (WHO) and standard obstetric guidelines (including Williams Obstetrics), the ideal number of antenatal care (ANC) visits in a low-risk pregnancy is: At least 12-14 visits throughout the pregnancy.(Option B,C and D ruled out)
  • This recommendation is based on evidence that frequent and regular visits improve maternal and fetal outcomes, including early detection and management of complications, health education, and emotional support.

questions.text: Which is not a feature of pseudocyesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Pseudocyesis: Phantom pregnancy/Spurious pregnancy/False pregnancy is a psychological disorder where the woman has a false but firm belief that she is pregnant, although no pregnancy exists.
  • The patient is often infertile and has an intense desire to have a baby.

Patient presents with:

  • Cessation of menstruation.
    • Enlargement of abdomen (due to deposition of fat).
    • Secretions from breasts.
    • Fetal movement (actually intestinal movement).

On examination:

  • No positive signs of pregnancy are found, i.e. fetal heart sound is not heard, no fetal movement felt and no fetal parts palpable by the examiner.

questions.text: Increased demand of following occurs in pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ideally the answer to this question should be none.As all the options given in the question have increased demand, some have more whereas in others it is marginal.
  • The best answer here would be vitamin B12as the increase in demand is marginal.
  • Daily dietary allowances for a woman of reproductive age, pregnancy and lactation.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman complains of lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting for several days. She denies sexually transmitted disease although she is sexually active with her boyfriend; they use condoms for protection. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks ago. Her blood pressure is 124/80 mm Hg, pulse is 90/ min, and temperature is 37.2° C(99.0° F). Abdominal examination demonstrates vague left lower quadrant tenderness without rebound or guarding. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix without cervical motion tenderness. No adnexal masses are appreciated. Results of a complete blood cell count and metabolic panel are within normal limits. Which of the following is the next best step in mgt?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • The patient presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and a history of sexual activity. Since pregnancy is the most common cause of secondary amenorrhea, the first step is to confirm it with a urine hCG test.(Option A,B and C ruled out)
  • If positive, the next step is an ultrasound to determine whether the pregnancy is intrauterine or extrauterine, as the question specifically asks for the next step in management.

questions.text: What is approx fetal weight, if height of uterus is above pubic symphysis is 35 cm and station of head is +2?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Estimation of fetal weight can be done using Johnson formula:
  • If station of head below ischial spine
  • [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm) - 11] × 155
  • If fetal head is at or above ischial spine-
  • [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm) - 12] × 155
  • Here the fetal head is at + 2, i.e., below the ischial spine, so it will be (35 - 11) × 155 = 3.7 kg.(Option A,B and D ruled out)

questions.text: Appropriate treatment of women having oedema in pregnancy includes:
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Femoral venous pressure is markedly raised in pregnancy especially in later months.
  • The pressure exerted by the gravid uterus on the common iliac veins (more on the right side due to dextrorotation of the uterus). causes pedal edema in pregnant women called physiological edema of pregnancy.
  • No treatment is required for physiological edema or orthostatic edema. It subsides on rest alone.(Option A ,B and C ruled out)
  • Diuretics should not be prescribed in case of physiological edema.

questions.text: Use of one of the following vaccinations is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Yellow fever vaccine is an attenuated live virus vaccine and is contraindicated in pregnancy. A simple "FUNDA" - (Proposed by CDC Society - 2002).
  • Killed vaccines are safe in pregnancy.
  • Live vaccines are best avoided in pregnancy.
  • Safety of Vaccines in Pregnancy:
    • Normally only tetanus toxoid is given in pregnancy.
    • Anti Rabies vaccine, if indicated can be given as usual.(Option C ruled out)
    • Cholera immunization may be given during epidemics.(Option B ruled out)
    • Hepatitis A and B vaccines are safe.(Option A ruled out)

questions.text: Theca lutein cyst is not seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Theca lutein cysts are bilateral cysts seen in ovaries associated with markedly elevated levels of hCG.
  • Conditions of pregnancy where theca lutein cysts are seen:
    • Molar pregnancy(Option A ruled out)
    • Diabetes
    • D alloimmunization Multifetal gestation (Option A ruled out)
    • Chronic renal failure- decreased clearance of hCG(Option C ruled out)
    • Hyperthyroidism (hCG and TSH-anatomically similar)

questions.text: Doppler ultrasound in pregnancy detect:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Doppler ultrasonography is a noninvasive technique to assess blood flow. It is useful for diagnosis of IUGR.
  • Doppler ultrasound in pregnancy primarily detects IUGR (Intrauterine Growth Restriction). It evaluates blood flow in the umbilical artery and other vessels to assess fetal well-being and placental function.

choices.text: Glucose challenge test with 50 gm of glucose

questions.text: A 29 years female G2P1 presents to an antenatal clinic at 24 weeks for routine check up. USG shows a normal for gestational age fetus at 24 weeks of gestation in frank breech position, with no other abnormalities. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is presenting to the antenatal clinic at 24 weeks for routine check up and a coincidental finding on USG is fetus at 24 weeks of gestation in frank breech position, with no other abnormalities.
  • At 24 weeks, breech position most of the times it spontaneously rotates and becomes cephalic at term.(options C , Option B , Option D are ruled out)
  • 24 weeks gestational age is the correct time for screening for gestational diabetes therefore we will do a glucose challenge test with 50 gm of glucose.

questions.text: Early deceleration denotes:
questions.solution:
Explanation:




  • A) Deceleration is defined as a decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 beats per minute or more.' Three basic patterns of deceleration are observed, each of which has a diagnostic significance
  • Early Deceleration (Normal - Head Compression)
    • Symmetrical, gradual ↓ in FHR with uterine contraction
    • Onset to nadir ≥ 30 seconds
    • Nadir coincides with peak of contraction
    • Onset, nadir, and recovery match beginning, peak, and end of contraction
    • Usually benign
  • Late Deceleration (Uteroplacental Insufficiency)
    • Symmetrical, gradual ↓ in FHR with contraction
    • Onset to nadir ≥ 30 seconds
    • Nadir occurs after the peak of contraction
    • Onset, nadir, and recovery are delayed compared to contraction
    • Suggests fetal hypoxia
  • Variable Deceleration (Cord Compression)
    • Abrupt ↓ in FHR (onset to nadir < 30 seconds)
    • Drop ≥ 15 bpm, lasting ≥ 15 sec but < 2 min
    • Timing, depth, and duration vary with contractions
    • Often shaped like V, U, or W on CTG
    • Common in cord compression
  • B) Baseline fetal heart rate = 110 TO 160 bpm
  • C) Beat to beat variability:
    • A baseline variability of 5-25 bpm is a sign of fetal well-being
  • D) Accelerations:
    • Accelerations are increased in FHR by 15 bpm or more lasting for at least 15 sec.
    • Accelerations denote an intact neurohormonal and cardiovascular activity and therefore denote a healthy fetus at >32weeks.

questions.text: All of the following are true about anencephaly except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Enlarged adrenal glands are not a feature of anencephaly
  • Anencephaly is characterized by absence of the cranium and telencephalic structures, with the skull base and orbits covered only by angiomatous stroma.
  • Acrania is the absence of the cranium, with protrusion of disorganized brain tissue. Open cranial defect allows leakage of AFP into amniotic fluid and maternal circulation. Leads to elevated maternal serum AFP, a key screening tool.(Option B ruled out)
  • Due to impaired fetal swallowing from absence of forebrain. Leads to accumulation of amniotic fluid → polyhydramnios.(Option D ruled out)
  • High-resolution ultrasound can detect anencephaly as early as 10-11 weeks (1st trimester)of gestation.(Option A ruled out)

questions.text: Open neural tube defects are best detected by increase in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Open neural tube defects (NTDs) such as anencephaly and open spina bifida cause fetal proteins to leak into the amniotic fluid and subsequently into maternal circulation
  • Acetylcholinesterase is elevated in most cases of open neural tube defects. It has got better diagnostic value than AFP.
  • Amniotic fluid alpha-fetoprotein/acetylcholinesterase determination is a diagnostic test; in contrast to maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein determination, which is a screening test.

Explanation of other options:

  • Pseudocholinesterase(Option B):Not relevant in the diagnosis of fetal anomalies.It is an enzyme involved in drug metabolism, mainly in adults.
  • AFP (Alpha-Fetoprotein) (Option C):Primary screening marker for open NTDs.Synthesized by the fetal yolk sac, liver, and GI tract.Leaked through the exposed neural tissue into amniotic fluid and maternal serum.Elevated maternal serum AFP in the second trimester suggests open NTDs or abdominal wall defects.
  • hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin)(Option D):Marker used in aneuploidy screening (e.g., Trisomy 21:elevated; Trisomy 18: decreased).Not used for NTD detection.

questions.text: Accurate diagnosis of anencephaly in ultrasound is seen at week:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • There are two aspects which should be considered while answering such a question.
    • Best time for diagnosis is ≥14 weeks(Option A,B and C ruled out)
    • Earliest time of detection
  • In case of anencephaly:
    • The diagnosis may be suspected in the first trimester during examination with an endovaginal probe but it is usually not certain until after 14 weeks.
    • Anencephaly can theoretically be diagnosed as early as 8 weeks; however it can be missed in the first trimester. In the second trimester, if an adequate ultrasound examination can be performed, anencephaly is diagnosed with virtually 100% accuracy.

questions.text: Hydrocephalus is best detected antenatally by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hydrocephalus is a condition in which there is an abnormal increase in cerebrospinal fluid within the ventricular and subarachnoid spaces of the brain.
  • The prenatal diagnosis of hydrocephalus is usually made by demonstration of a dilated ventricular system in an ultrasound examination.(Option A,B and C ruled out)
  • Earliest and most accurate sonographic sign of hydrocephalus:
    • Enlarged lateral ventricles.
    • The lateral ventricle is measured at the level of the atrium.
  • Other signs of hydrocephalus on USG:
    • Dangling choroid plexuses
    • Thinning out of the cerebral cortex
  • Hence once diagnosed on USG-Karyotyping and TORCH test should be done to know the etiology

questions.text: Preconceptional intake of which of the following results in decrease in incidence of neural tube defect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Folic acid has been shown to effectively reduce the risk of neural tube defects (NTDs) by 50%. A daily 4 mg dose is recommended for patients who have had a previous pregnancy affected by neural tube defects. It should be started at least 1 month (ideally 3 months) prior to pregnancy and continued through the first 6-12 weeks of pregnancy.(Option A,C and D ruled out)
  • Therapeutic dose of folic acid (to be given in females with a previous history of baby with NTD) - 4 mg.
  • Prophylactic dose of folic acid = 0.4 mg i.e., 400 mg
  • Duration: It should be started 1 month before conception and continued till 3 months of pregnancy.
  • Women with insulin dependent diabetes mellitus and those with seizure disorders treated by valproic acid and carbamazepine are also at greater risk for NTD's and should be given therapeutic dose of folic acid i.e 4 mg.

questions.text: Anencephaly is best diagnosed using:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Earlier approach to NTD diagnosis:
    • Elevated maternal serum AFP → prompted amniocentesis.(Option A ruled out)
    • Amniotic fluid AFP measured next.(Option B ruled out)
    • If elevated, acetylcholinesterase (AChE) assay was done.
    • A combination of ↑ AFP + positive AChE was considered diagnostic for open neural tube defects.
  • Current practice:
    • High-resolution ultrasonography alone can detect nearly 100% of NTDs.
  • Thus, ultrasound has largely replaced biochemical testing for NTD diagnosis.
  • Diagnosis of Anencephaly/NTD in brief:
    • Screening test for NTD: Maternal serum alpha protein (between 14 and 22 weeks, best at 16 weeks).
    • The best marker for NTD/Open spina bifida/ Anencephaly is Acetylcholinesterase.
    • Best investigation for Anencephaly-ultrasound.
    • The best time for diagnosis of Anencephaly is 14 weeks by USG.
    • Earliest diagnosis of Anencephaly by 10 weeks.
    • The best investigation for hydrocephalus is Ultrasound.(Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Lemon sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Classical signs of spina bifida on USG are:
    • Lemon sign - frontal bone scalloping
    • Banana sign - downward displacement of the cerebellum
  • Anencephaly shows frog-eye sign (option B ruled out) and Agenesis of corpus callosum shows sunburst sign on mri.(Option C ruled out)

questions.text: The presence of acetylcholinesterase in amniotic fluid is most indicative of which of the following fetal conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Amniotic fluid Acetylcholinesterase level is elevated in open neural tube defect like open spina bifida.
    • It has a better diagnostic value than AFP.
    • In case of suspected neural tube defect, on Amniocentesis, if amniotic fluid AFP levels are raised but Acetyl- cholinesterase levels are normal, patient should be reassured that elevated AFP levels are probably caused by fetal blood contamination but, if acetylcholinesterase is also elevated along with AFP, it is indicative of NTD.
    • It also helps to distinguish between neural tube defect and abdominal wall defects (both of which cause elevated MSAFP):
      • Acetylcholinesterase is raised in open NTD, but is low in abdominal wall defects.
      • In patients with NTD, the ratio of acetylcholinesterase to butyrylcholinesterase levels is 0.14 or more. In case of abdominal wall defects, this ratio is less than 0.14.

Explanation of other options:

  • Gastroschisis(Option B): Can raise AFP due to open abdominal wall, but AChE remains negative.
  • Omphalocele(Option C): Also may elevate AFP, but covered by a sac → no AChE leakage.
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta(Option D):Genetic bone disorder, no AFP or AChE elevation.
